description: From Middle English hond, hand, from Old English hand, from Proto-West Germanic *handu, from Proto-Germanic *handuz.

See also Dutch, Norwegian Nynorsk, Swedish hand, Danish hånd, German Hand, West Frisian hân). Perhaps compare Old Swedish hinna (“to gain”), Gothic 𐍆𐍂𐌰-𐌷𐌹𐌽𐌸𐌰𐌽 (fra-hinþan, “to take captive, capture”); and Latvian sīts (“hunting spear”), Ancient Greek κεντέω (kentéō, “prick”), Albanian çandër (“pitchfork, prop”).

entries.meaning: The part of the forelimb below the forearm or wrist in a human, and the corresponding part in many other animals.
examples: Meronyms: index finger, middle finger, palm, pinky, ring finger, thumb

definitionGroups.group: That which resembles, or to some extent performs the office of, a human hand.

entries.meaning: A limb of certain animals, such as the foot of a hawk, or any one of the four extremities of a monkey.
An index or pointer on a dial; such as the hour and minute hands on the face of an analog clock, which are used to indicate the time of day.

definitionGroups.group: That which is, or may be, held in a hand at once.

entries.meaning: (card games) The set of cards held by a player.
A round of a card game.
(tobacco manufacturing) A bundle of tobacco leaves tied together.
(collective) A bunch of bananas.

definitionGroups.group: That which has the appearance of, a human hand.

entries.meaning: A bunch of bananas, a typical retail amount, where individual fruits are fingers.
(chiefly in measuring the height of horses) Four inches, a hand's breadth.
(obsolete) Three inches.
A side; part, camp; direction, either right or left.
Power of performance; means of execution; ability; skill; dexterity.
(especially in compounds) An agent; a servant, or manual laborer; a workman, trained or competent for special service or duty.
examples: Large farms need many farm hands.

entries.meaning: A performer more or less skilful.
examples: an old hand at public speaking

entries.meaning: An instance of helping.
examples: Bob gave Alice a hand to move the furniture.

entries.meaning: Handwriting; style of penmanship.
A person's autograph or signature.
examples: Given under my Hand and Seal of the State this 1st Day of January, 2010.

entries.meaning: Promise, word; especially of a betrothal.
examples: They once made Mourning and Fasting for the Death of the English Governor, who had given his Hand to come on such a Day to 'em, and neither came nor sent; believing, when a Man's Word was past, nothing but Death could or should prevent his keeping it: And when they saw he was not dead, they ask'd him what Name they had for a Man who promis'd a Thing he did not do?

entries.meaning: Personal possession; ownership.
examples: Receiving in hand one year’s tribute.

entries.meaning: (usually in the plural, hands) Management, domain, control.
examples: in safe hands;  in good hands;  He lost his job when the factory changed hands.  With the business back in the founder's hands, there is new hope for the company.  With John in charge of the project, it's in good hands.

entries.meaning: Applause.
(historical) A Native American gambling game, involving guessing the whereabouts of bits of ivory or similar, which are passed rapidly from hand to hand.
(firearms) The small part of a gunstock near the lock, which is grasped by the hand in taking aim.
A whole rhizome of ginger.
The feel of a fabric; the impression or quality of the fabric as judged qualitatively by the sense of touch.
examples: This fabric has a smooth, soft hand.

entries.meaning: (archaic) Actual performance; deed; act; workmanship; agency; hence, manner of performance.
(archaic) Agency in transmission from one person to another.
examples: to buy at first hand (from the producer, or when new);  to buy at second hand (when no longer in the producer’s hand, or when not new);  It's not a rumor. I heard it at first hand.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Rate; price.

description: From Middle English handen, honden, from the noun (see above); and also from henden (> English hend), from Old English *hendan, ġehendan (“to seize by hand, grasp, hold”), from Proto-West Germanic *handijan, from Proto-Germanic *handijaną (“to take by hand, grasp”), from the noun (see above). Cognate with Old Frisian handa, henda (“to grasp, seize”), Middle Low German handen, henden (in derivatives), Dutch handen, henden (“to arrange, dispose, be handy”), Dutch overhandigen (“to hand, hand over”), Middle High German handen (“to cut, hew”), Middle High German henden (“to give hands to; take hold of, seize”), Old Norse henda (“to grasp, seize, take by hand”).

verbs.description: hand (third-person singular simple present hands, present participle handing, simple past and past participle handed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give, pass or transmit with the hand, literally or figuratively.
examples: He handed them the letter.   She handed responsibility over to her deputy.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To lead, guide, or assist with the hand; to conduct.
examples: to hand a lady into a carriage

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To manage.
(transitive, obsolete) To seize; to lay hands on.
(transitive, rare) To pledge by the hand; to handfast.
(transitive, nautical, said of a sail) To furl.
examples: send the people up to hand the sail, and when up, before they goon the yard, I'll clap the rolling tackle on to  steady it

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete) To cooperate.
